questions.question: 1. Which of the following represents a homogeneous array (all elements of the same type)?

explanations.a: Correct. This is a homogeneous array with all integer elements.
explanations.b: Incorrect. This array contains mixed types (character, integer, and string).
explanations.c: Incorrect. This array contains mixed types (strings, boolean, and character).
explanations.d: Incorrect. This array contains mixed types (boolean, integer, and float).

questions.question: 2. Which of the following is an array sorted in ascending order?

explanations.a: Incorrect. -10 must appear at the beginning and not the end as it is the smallest element.
explanations.b: Incorrect. -13 is smaller than -10, so they must be swapped.
explanations.c: Correct. This array is properly sorted in ascending order: -1000 < 0 < 14 < 27.
explanations.d: Incorrect. This sequence is in descending order and must be reversed.

questions.question: 3. Which of the following is not a sorting algorithm?

explanations.a: Incorrect. This is a popular sorting algorithm which is covered by this very experiment.
explanations.b: Incorrect. This is another popular sorting algorithm.
explanations.c: Incorrect. This is another popular sorting algorithm.
explanations.d: Correct. Binary search is not a sorting algorithm but is in fact an algorithm to search for a specific element in a sorted array.

questions.question: 4. Consider the following array: A = [-1, 9, 4, 8] Identify A[2], i.e, the element with index 2 from the following (assume 0-indexed array).

explanations.a: Incorrect. Array indexing begins at 0 and this is the 0th element, i.e, A[0].
explanations.b: Incorrect. Array indexing begins at 0 and this is the element with index 1, i.e, A[1].
explanations.c: Correct. Array indexing begins at 0 and this is the element with index 2, i.e, A[2].
explanations.d: Incorrect. Array indexing begins at 0 and this is the element with index 3, i.e, A[3].

questions.question:
5. Consider the following pseudo-code:
for i = 0 to 2
  for j = 0 to i
    print "*"
  print newline
end
Predict the output of the above code.

explanations.a: Correct. When i=0, j loops once (0 to 0) printing 1 asterisk. When i=1, j loops twice (0 to 1) printing 2 asterisks. When i=2, j loops three times (0 to 2) printing 3 asterisks.
explanations.b: Incorrect. This output ignores the inner j loop which determines how many asterisks are printed per line.
explanations.c: Incorrect. This output shows reverse order, which would require the loop condition to be different.
explanations.d: Incorrect. This output ignores the newline printing after each iteration of the outer loop.
